trans-unit.source: How to use CDN | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use CDN | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN) to deliver high-bandwidth content by caching blobs and static content.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN) to deliver high-bandwidth content by caching blobs and static content.

trans-unit.source: Using CDN for Azure
trans-unit.target: Using CDN for Azure

trans-unit.source: The Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN) is the fundamental building block to scale any HTTP application in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN) is the fundamental building block to scale any HTTP application in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It offers Azure customers a global solution by caching and delivering content close to end users.
trans-unit.target: It offers Azure customers a global solution by caching and delivering content close to end users.

trans-unit.source: As a result, instead of hitting origin every single time, user requests get intelligently routed to the best performed CDN edge POP.
trans-unit.target: As a result, instead of hitting origin every single time, user requests get intelligently routed to the best performed CDN edge POP.

trans-unit.source: This significantly increases the performance and user experience.
trans-unit.target: This significantly increases the performance and user experience.

trans-unit.source: For a current list of
trans-unit.target: For a current list of

trans-unit.source: CDN node locations, see [Azure CDN Node Locations].
trans-unit.target: CDN node locations, see [Azure CDN Node Locations].

trans-unit.source: The benefits of using CDN to cache Azure data include:
trans-unit.target: The benefits of using CDN to cache Azure data include:

trans-unit.source: Better performance and user experience for end users who are far from a content source, and are using applications where many 'internet trips' are required to load content
trans-unit.target: Better performance and user experience for end users who are far from a content source, and are using applications where many 'internet trips' are required to load content

trans-unit.source: Large distributed scale to better handle instantaneous high load, say, at the start of an event such as a product launch
trans-unit.target: Large distributed scale to better handle instantaneous high load, say, at the start of an event such as a product launch

trans-unit.source: By distributing user requests and serving content from global edge POPs, less traffic is sent to origin thus offload the origin.
trans-unit.target: By distributing user requests and serving content from global edge POPs, less traffic is sent to origin thus offload the origin.

trans-unit.source: Existing CDN customers can now use the Azure CDN in the [Azure Management Portal].
trans-unit.target: Existing CDN customers can now use the Azure CDN in the [Azure Management Portal].

trans-unit.source: The CDN is an add-on feature to your subscription and has a separate [billing plan].
trans-unit.target: The CDN is an add-on feature to your subscription and has a separate [billing plan].

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a CDN origin in Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a CDN origin in Azure

trans-unit.source: CDN origin is the location from which CDN fetch content and cache at the edge POPs.
trans-unit.target: CDN origin is the location from which CDN fetch content and cache at the edge POPs.

trans-unit.source: The integrated Azure origin includes Azure Apps, Cloud Services, Storage and Media services.
trans-unit.target: The integrated Azure origin includes Azure Apps, Cloud Services, Storage and Media services.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a CDN endpoint pointing to your Azure origin
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a CDN endpoint pointing to your Azure origin

trans-unit.source: Once your origin is set up, it will be available in the origin list when you <link><linkText>create a new CDN endpoint</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Once your origin is set up, it will be available in the origin list when you <link><linkText>create a new CDN endpoint</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The configuration created for the endpoint will not immediately be available; it can take up to 60 minutes for the registration to propagate through the CDN network.
trans-unit.target: The configuration created for the endpoint will not immediately be available; it can take up to 60 minutes for the registration to propagate through the CDN network.

trans-unit.source: Users who try to use the CDN domain name immediately may receive status code 400 (Bad Request) until the content is available via the CDN.
trans-unit.target: Users who try to use the CDN domain name immediately may receive status code 400 (Bad Request) until the content is available via the CDN.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Set up your CDN configuration
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Set up your CDN configuration

trans-unit.source: You can enable a number of features for your CDN endpoint, such as caching policy, query string caching, etc.
trans-unit.target: You can enable a number of features for your CDN endpoint, such as caching policy, query string caching, etc.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Access CDN content
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Access CDN content

trans-unit.source: To access cached content on the CDN, use the CDN URL provided in the portal. For example, the address for a cached blob will be similar to the following: http://<html></html>.vo.msecnd.net/<html></html>/<html></html>
trans-unit.target: To access cached content on the CDN, use the CDN URL provided in the portal. For example, the address for a cached blob will be similar to the following: http://<html></html>.vo.msecnd.net/<html></html>/<html></html>

trans-unit.source: See also
trans-unit.target: See also

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Overview of the Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN)</linkText><title></title></link>
